I regret not being a better friend to a woman about 15 years ago. I eventually found out she had a recurring cancer but at the time I didn't know the depth of her illness. She was bright, intelligent, and engaging, funny and so sweet. An accomplished author and instructor, we met at an authors event - I purchased her book, we chatted and she signed it for me. We stayed in touch, occasionally meeting for coffee, happy hour etc. She could even dance (ballroom) and delighted finding that I could as well. Once, at a Starbucks, we danced a impromptu two-step on the patio. We laughed and had fun.
She asked me several times to do other things with her but for various reasons (work, etc) I declined. I realize now these were important to her, activities that would have brought her joy that I could have easily done. Her illness returned and we had planned to walk an art fair together but she was too sick. I saw her once at the hospital and she died from cancer shortly after. I loved her so much.
I regret not spending more quality time with my parents when they were at the end of their life and not being beside them at the moment when they passed away.

At the age of 41, I had an affair with another woman while still married to my husband of almost 20 years.  I subsequently divorced my husband and left my 10 year old son in the custody of his father.   Although I was very unhappy in my marriage, my regret is the pain and hurt I inflicted on my son.  I regret not finding a less damaging way to leave my husband.  My actions were morally bankrupt and caused irreparable damage to my son, my husband and myself.
married the wrong man. could not figure a way out of that marriage
I was closeted as a teen and had a couple sexual experiences with a best friend who I loved romantically.  I regret never telling him that I loved him.

Same experience like "Bruce" I had 50 years ago ....a perfectly sort of "love at first sight" - barely a glance at her even from a distance of at least 100 feet . ..and my heart/soul was desperate to befriend her (in those days of late 1960s talking to a girl for more than few minutes was no no..) and it was unique sort of attachment in just a month or so but soon after summer she went to college in another town, couple of innocent but strong emotional letters exchanged and then, very suddenly, a boy who had come from U.S. to India to marry took her away as part of arranged  marriage....she wrote me from there....back and forth innocent but emotional exchanges of letters, which later stopped,.....and 50 years later yes the REGRET (of not being able to say or confess - from both of us - beyond friendship level because yet still being in college was not the time to think of marriage or tell parents) is indeed still haunting especially when the Sun of life is seen setting on the Horizon

I met a man attending Prescott College in Arizona. I was 20 and he was 22. We had a beautiful and powerful connection for 3 months. He flew off to Equador with friends, and I moved to Brazil. The next summer he traveled to work on a cattle ranch in Brazil with hopes of finding me. I'd written him a letter to meet me on a certain day at the right edge of Copacabana Beach in Rio de Janeiro. He showed up. I REGRET I did not show up to meet him that day. We wrote a few letters back and forth then became separated. Miraculously, we reconnected after 37 years apart and one year later, we married.

I eloped in my second year of university. I was the first in my family to attend college, and I paused my studies. I promised my Dad, who passed before seeing me graduate, that I would go back to my top tier alma mater, and I never did. While I did go on to complete my degree and two additional graduate degrees, I didn't do it where I wanted and how, as I promised my father. I cry every time I see the university in person, and always wonder what life would have been like had I returned.

For me it's a bit hard to say. For one hand I don't believe so much in the concept of regret. I like to think that every choice I made over the years are in a way responsible for who I'm today and I'm mostly proud of myself. So silly regrets like not learning a third language? Yes, but maybe "regret" is a strong word for that feeling. But in the end, wouldn't call it a regret itself but a wish. A wish to live life. I think although regret is a concept I don't fully "believe", is one that pushes me forward. The fear of regrets is more than a fuel than the regret itself. By the end I know I won't regret. I know that I'll do my best. As this idea, the need to avoid the regret, will keep me in line.

I regret that I have lived most of my life feeling not beautiful, or even pretty, enough, and certainly not thin enough—and therefore not worthy enough to live without apology for not being perfect. I have considered myself unworthy of a person’s love—or even interest—many, many times. And then felt betrayed when that person fell in love with someone I judged no more attractive than I was. I regret the perfectionism, the fear of humiliation, that stopped me from living a bolder, more true life, and getting my imperfect art out in the world. I regret that I go years without swimming in public. I regret that I have been poisoned by my own judgments my whole life. I’ve judged myself before even leaving the starting line, rushed to make myself smaller and more “careful” before anyone else could judge me. I regret that I sucked every negative response or comment I’ve ever received right into my inner core and let it fester there.

I dropped out of college at 18. I eventually went back and got my degree, but it took years to recover and going back was a very different experience; I was older than everyone else and connected on a different level and majored in something I was much less passionate about. I never felt like my life went in the direction I'd hoped--it feels like my entire life is a "Plan B" with significantly lower expectations, and not in a good way. I have an ok job now, but I feel like I left myself and my hopes and dreams back there and have never been able to recover them, not even in therapy.
